channel.title: Gardens of the Roman Empire
channel.description: Recent content on Gardens of the Roman Empire

item.title: Rural Villa in Winden Am See
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Winden Am See Winden Am See (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Winden Am See Keywords corridors rural villas vestibules villae rusticae Garden Description The modest house of this villa rustica is of the so-called corridor type, a type common in the region and already seen at Carnuntum (Fig. 1). It was built around 100 A.D. and occupied until the 4th century.

item.title: Tomb Garden of Iul(ia) Victorin(a) in Scarbantia
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Scarbantia Scarbantia (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Iul(ia) Victorin(a) in Scarbantia Keywords epitaphs stelae tombs viridarium Garden Description A limestone funerary stele of probably third century date unearthed in 1973 near Scarbantia at Winder am See (Burgenland) and now in the Burgenländische Landesmuseum at Eisenstadt records an epitaph set up by Septimius Alcides, a veteran of the legio XIII Gemina Iulia, for his wife, Iul(ia) Victorin(a), dead at thirty, for whom he built at his own expense a funerary pleasure garden (viridarium).

item.title: Tomb Garden of Fl(avius) Dalmatius in Savaria
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Savaria Savaria (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Fl(avius) Dalmatius in Savaria Keywords epitaphs tombs Garden Description A limestone slab found near the monastery of St. Martin in Szombathely (Savaria), Hungary, in 1845 and subsequently transferred to the National Museum in Budapest records the epitaph of a high ranking equestrian official (vir perfectissimus), Fl(avius) Dalmatius, and his wife Aur(elia) Iulia, who some time during the third or fourth century built a tomb on their villa estate and composed for it a verse inscription in which Dalmatius hopes for commemoration from a future owner of the property: “Whoever will be master of this house and garden after me, gather the nearby roses for me, put out the white lilies which the green garden will grow for me: these are the gifts of the blessed” (Quisquis {h}e(ris) post me d(o)m(inus) Laris huius et (h)orti, / vicinas mihi carpe rosas, mihi lilia pone / [ca]ndeda{s} q(uae) viridis dabit (h)ortulus: ista (sc.

item.title: Rural Villa in Eisenstadt
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Eisenstadt Eisenstadt (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Eisenstadt Keywords altars (religious fixtures) atriums peristyles (Roman courtyards) podiums (building divisions) porticoes rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description The residence of this villa rustica was entered on the southeast by a portico (Fig. 1). After passing through a room interpreted as the atrium, one arrived in the open courtyard which had a peristyle on three sides (G on plan).

item.title: Urban Houses in Carnuntum
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Carnuntum Carnuntum (Pleiades) Location Description The town of Carnuntum on the Danube River, like Aquincum, was promoted to colonial status in 194 A.D., after having been a municipium. Excavations in the modern zoological garden have revealed part of the town plan and its residential district. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban Houses in Carnuntum Keywords arcades (structural assemblies) corridors vestibules Garden Description The regional house type found often in Pannonia, the so-called corridor house, is characterized by a vestibule or arcade on its narrow front and a central corridor running the length of the house, separating it into two parts.

item.title: Urban House or Schola in Aquincum
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Aquincum Aquincum (Pleiades) Location Description This town on the Danube river acquired the rank of municipium under Hadrian in 124 A.D. In the year 194 it was granted colonial status. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban House or Schola in Aquincum Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) fountains peristyles (Roman courtyards) piscinae Garden Description Very few houses of Mediterranean type have been discovered, and only one can be said with certainty to have had a garden (Fig.

item.title: Villa of Herodes Atticus
item.description: Province Achaea Province Description Roman intervention in Greek political affairs resulted in conflicts that led to the destruction of Corinth in 146 B.C. and the sacking of Athens in 86 B.C. It was not until 27 B.C., however, that Augustus formally organized the Roman province of Achaea. Achaea consisted of the cities and territories of the southern Greek mainland between the Peloponnese and Thessaly, as well as Epirus in the northwest and the Ionian and some of the Aegean islands.

item.title: Gardens of Epicurus
item.description: Province Achaea Province Description Roman intervention in Greek political affairs resulted in conflicts that led to the destruction of Corinth in 146 B.C. and the sacking of Athens in 86 B.C. It was not until 27 B.C., however, that Augustus formally organized the Roman province of Achaea. Achaea consisted of the cities and territories of the southern Greek mainland between the Peloponnese and Thessaly, as well as Epirus in the northwest and the Ionian and some of the Aegean islands.

item.title: Rural Villa in Winkel-Seeb
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Winkel-Seeb Winkel-Seeb (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Winkel-Seeb Keywords barrier walls rural villas villae rusticae well houses Garden Description The residential and service parts of this villa rustica occupied an area of ca. 7 hectares. The lateral walls of the complex could be followed over a length of 395 meters, but it is assumed that they once extended up to the lake southeast of the farm.

item.title: Rural Villa in Wiesbaden-Biebrich
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Wiesbaden-Biebrich Wiesbaden-Biebrich (Pleiades) Location Description Biebrich, now part of Wiesbaden, is directly on the right bank of the Rhein south of the center of Wiesbaden. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Wiesbaden-Biebrich Keywords barrier walls rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description Only the residential part of this farm has been excavated. The house with a width of 22 meters had two protruding wings at the south.

item.title: Structures under the Collège Lumière in Vesontio
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Vesontio Vesontio (Pleiades) Location Description The defensibility offered by this unique geography made Caesar hasten to occupy Vesontio in 58 BC. The town came to have all the usual Roman structures– forum, baths, aqueduct, and amphitheater (on the other side of the Doubs, to the northwest.) But the most visible remnant is the Porte Noire (Black Gate) [3], a triumphal arch built by Marcus Aurelius at the southeastern end of the cardo maximus, today Grande Rue and still the center of city life.

item.title: House in the Rue du Palais de Justice in Vesontio
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Vesontio Vesontio (Pleiades) Location Description The defensibility offered by this unique geography made Caesar hasten to occupy Vesontio in 58 BC. The town came to have all the usual Roman structures– forum, baths, aqueduct, and amphitheater (on the other side of the Doubs, to the northwest.) But the most visible remnant is the Porte Noire (Black Gate) [3], a triumphal arch built by Marcus Aurelius at the southeastern end of the cardo maximus, today Grande Rue and still the center of city life.

item.title: Villa in Vallon (Sur Dompierre, Canton de Fribourg, Switzerland)
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Vallon Vallon (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Villa in Vallon (Sur Dompierre, Canton de Fribourg, Switzerland) Keywords arbors barrier walls ceramic tile fences (site elements) hearths horrea mosaics (visual works) pedestals pillars piscinae porticoes rural villas sherds tesserae villae rusticae water supply systems Garden Description Located 6km south-east of Avenches/ Aventicum, the capital of the Helvetian tribe, this site is situated on a small alluvial terrace at the bottom of a hillside.

item.title: Rural Villa in Orbe
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Orbe Orbe (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Orbe Keywords barrier walls rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description This large palatial house belonged to a villa rustica revealed by excavation and aerial photography. The enclosed farmyard is calculated to have been approximately 420 x 650 meters in size. The house itself, built in the mid-1st century AD and in use until the 4th century, was 200 meters long (Fig.

item.title: Rural Villa in Oberentfelden
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Oberentfelden Oberentfelden (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Oberentfelden Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) nymphaea (garden structures) rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description The enclosed area of this villa rustica was 160 meters wide and at least 460 meters long; the eastern limits of the complex have not yet been found. The main residence and bath complex (A and B in Fig.

item.title: Rural Villa in Hummetroth
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Hummetroth Hummetroth (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Hummetroth Keywords apsed triclinium bathhouses (water recreation structures) porticoes rural villas terrace gardens villae rusticae Garden Description The enclosed farmyard, including the residential area (pars urbana) and the service zone with outbuildings and working areas (pars rustica), covered an area of 3.5 hectares. The house of this villa rustica of the 2nd century is of the winged corridor type with two protruding wings framing a large courtyard in front of the house at the south (Fig.

item.title: The Circus of Roman Corinth
item.description: Province Achaea Province Description Roman intervention in Greek political affairs resulted in conflicts that led to the destruction of Corinth in 146 B.C. and the sacking of Athens in 86 B.C. It was not until 27 B.C., however, that Augustus formally organized the Roman province of Achaea. Achaea consisted of the cities and territories of the southern Greek mainland between the Peloponnese and Thessaly, as well as Epirus in the northwest and the Ionian and some of the Aegean islands.

item.title: Tomb Garden of Ti. Claudios Lykos
item.description: Province Macedonia Province Description Location Thessaloniki Thessaloniki (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Ti. Claudios Lykos Keywords tombs sarcophagi epitaphs Garden Description A limestone sarcophagus found at Thessaloniki and first reported in 1962 preserves an epitaph set up in 147 A.D. by Ti. Claudios Lykos, a local town counselor (bouleutÆw), for himself, his loving wife Meinoukia (Minucia) Theoprepes, and his two daughters Roda and Theoprepes. As Robert correctly observed (Bull.

item.title: Rural Villa in Friedberg Pfingstweide
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Friedberg Pfingstweide Friedberg Pfingstweide (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Friedberg Pfingstweide Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description This villa rustica was situated on the northern slope of a valley through which a stream ran. The enclosed area of the farm occupied an area of 3.4 hectares (180 x 190 meters), and it was divided into a residential part (pars urbana) and a service area (pars rustica) by a road running east-west (Fig.

item.title: Rural Villa in Ferpicloz
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Ferpicloz Ferpicloz (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Ferpicloz Keywords barrier walls porticoes rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description The house of this villa rustica was of the winged corridor type (A in Fig. 1) with a porticoed facade (Fig. 1). Attached to the eastern end of the house, measuring 37 x 46 meters, was a wall running east-west which has been interpreted as the protective wall of a garden (G in Fig.

item.title: Rural Villa in Dietikon
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Dietikon Dietikon (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Dietikon Keywords axial plan piscinae porticoes rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description This villa rustica complex was built on a site at the bottom of a valley near and parallel to the river Limmat. Dietikon was situated on an important land and water traffic route from the Bündner Alps to Vindonissa and further north to the Rhine.

item.title: Rural Villa in Bad Kreuznach
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Bad Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Bad Kreuznach Keywords apsed triclinium colonnades fountains lararia mosaics (visual works) peristyles (Roman courtyards) porticoes rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description This villa, almost 6000 square meters in size, gives eloquent testimony to the wealth and status of the owner of the rural estate. The estate was built in the second half of the 2nd century and occupied until its destruction around 275.

item.title: House in Insula 16 in Aventicum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Aventicum Aventicum (Pleiades) Location Description The town was established in the Augustan period as the civitas capital of the Helvetii. At this time the orthogonal street grid was laid out. Most probably in AD 71, it became Colonia Pia Flavia Constans Emerita Helvetiorum Foederata. The town was destroyed or badly damaged around AD 260, and it was progressively abandoned thereafter. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden House in Insula 16 in Aventicum

item.title: Cemetery Garden of Metrodorus
item.description: Province Dalmatia Province Description Location Salona Salona (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Cemetery Garden of Metrodorus Keywords tombs epitaphs sarcophagi (coffins) Garden Description A sarcophagus found at Salona in 1824, transported to the museum in Split, and subsequently lost bore an inscription recording the donation by Aur(elius) Aprilianus to Aur(elius) Amurus and Aur(elia) Quinta of a sarcophagus “which is in the garden of Metrodorus” and specifying that it was put into position while they were still alive (Aur(elius) Aprilianus se vivo donavet arcam Aur(elio) Amuro et Aur(eliae) Quinte que est in orto Metrodori.

item.title: House in Insula 13 in Aventicum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Aventicum Aventicum (Pleiades) Location Description The town was established in the Augustan period as the civitas capital of the Helvetii. At this time the orthogonal street grid was laid out. Most probably in AD 71, it became Colonia Pia Flavia Constans Emerita Helvetiorum Foederata. The town was destroyed or badly damaged around AD 260, and it was progressively abandoned thereafter. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden House in Insula 13 in Aventicum

item.title: Tomb Garden with Monument of Julia Mutiana
item.description: Province Dalmatia Province Description Location Salona Salona (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden and Pool of Cingius Iustinus Keywords tombs epitaphs Garden Description An inscription reported among those of Salona records an epitaph set up by Iulia Mutiana for herself and her husband Aur(elius) Pateas in a place granted her by A. Aelius Marullinus “among the sarcophagi in the middle in the garden, near the road, overlooking the old (?

item.title: Tomb Garden and Pool of Cingius Iustinus
item.description: Province Dalmatia Province Description Location Salona Salona (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden and Pool of Cingius Iustinus Keywords piscinae tombs epitaphs Garden Description A rock cut inscription at Salonae marks the spot where some time in the late second or third century Cingius Iustinus made a fishpond or pool (piscina) in the garden of his wife Aelia Licinia for her and for himself (fecit piscinam in horto Aeliae Liciniae coiugi incomparabili et sibi).

item.title: Palatial House in Insula 7 in Aventicum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Aventicum Aventicum (Pleiades) Location Description The town was established in the Augustan period as the civitas capital of the Helvetii. At this time the orthogonal street grid was laid out. Most probably in AD 71, it became Colonia Pia Flavia Constans Emerita Helvetiorum Foederata. The town was destroyed or badly damaged around AD 260, and it was progressively abandoned thereafter. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Palatial House in Insula 7 in Aventicum

item.title: House in Insula 30 in Augusta Raurica
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Augusta Raurica Augusta Raurica (Pleiades) Location Description The town on the Rhine River possessed colonial status since the late 1st century BC. The street grid, as well as many public and residential buildings, are well known from excavations. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden House in Insula 30 in Augusta Raurica Keywords barrier walls colonnades insulae peristyles (Roman courtyards) triclinia water wells Garden Description Insula 30, east of the central baths, was taken up by a single house built around 200 AD.

item.title: House in Insula 1 and 2 in Augusta Raurica
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Augusta Raurica Augusta Raurica (Pleiades) Location Description The town on the Rhine River possessed colonial status since the late 1st century BC. The street grid, as well as many public and residential buildings, are well known from excavations. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden House in Insula 1 and 2 in Augusta Raurica Keywords barrier walls insulae peristyles (Roman courtyards) porticoes terrace gardens Garden Description This house, built on sloping terrain on the northern edge of the city around AD 150, was enlarged twenty years later to incorporate at least two certain gardens (Fig.

item.title: Large Building North of Forum in Arae Flaviae
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Arae Flaviae Arae Flaviae (Pleiades) Location Description This town on the Neckar river was granted municipal status around 84 AD or slightly later. In modern terms, it lies about halfway between Zurich and Stuttgart. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Large Building north of Forum in Arae Flaviae Keywords colonnades peristyles (Roman courtyards) Garden Description This building ca. 95 meters in width consisted of several units built at different times.

item.title: Tomb Garden of Anonymous Gaul in Andematunnum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Andematunnum Andematunnum (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Anonymous Gaul in Andematunnum Keywords former reservoirs mausoleums orchards tombs Garden Description A famous inscription from the territory of the Lingonian Gauls (Langres) known only from a manuscript of the tenth century records the will of a local hunting enthusiast who built for himself a lavish mausoleum (cella memoriae) and equipped it with orchards (pomaria) and a reservoir (lacus) put in the care of two freedmen who are instructed to devote the revenues from them to upkeep of the tomb complex, and three landscape gardeners (topiarii) and their apprentices, each to be supported annually by the testator’s grandson, Sex.

item.title: Rural Villa at Neerhaaren-Rekem
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Neerhaaren-Rekem Neerhaaren-Rekem (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural villa at Neerhaaren-Rekem Keywords rural villas villae rusticae arbors pergolas piscinae Garden Description The facade of this modest house of a villa rustica near the Meuse river measured 24 m. in length and had two protruding wings joined by a portico (Plan 1). The house was built in the late 1st century A.D. There is evidence for an arbor or pergola next to the house in the form of two rows of postholes arranged diagonally and converging in front of the entrance on the west (circles on plan).

item.title: The Houses of Insula 7 in Colonia Ulpia Traiana
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Xanten Xanten (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Industrial quarter Sublocation Description This insula southeast of the forum is commonly referred to as an industrial quarter (Plan 1). It was divided into several long, narrow plots on which were houses, shops and workshops. Garden The houses of Insula 7 in Colonia Ulpia Traiana (Xanten) Keywords insulae kitchen gardens courtyards Garden Description Between the buildings were open areas, some paved and equipped with ovens and pottery kilns, wells and latrines, others unpaved.

item.title: Urban House on Lungenstrasse
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Cologne Cologne (Pleiades) Location Description This large town on the west bank of the Rhine river was the civitas capital of the Ubii in the first half of the 1st century A.D. It was granted the status of colonia by Claudius in 50 and became the provincial capital in 85. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban house on Lungenstrasse (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium) Keywords peristyles (Roman courtyards)

item.title: Urban House on Wolfsstrasse
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Cologne Cologne (Pleiades) Location Description This large town on the west bank of the Rhine river was the civitas capital of the Ubii in the first half of the 1st century A.D. It was granted the status of colonia by Claudius in 50 and became the provincial capital in 85. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban house on Wolfsstrasse (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium) Keywords urban villas villae urbanae

item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Cologne Cologne (Pleiades) Location Description This large town on the west bank of the Rhine river was the civitas capital of the Ubii in the first half of the 1st century A.D. It was granted the status of colonia by Claudius in 50 and became the provincial capital in 85. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban house on Gertrudenstrasse (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium) Keywords urban villas villae urbanae

item.title: Tomb Garden of Ael(ius) Iul(ius) Iulianus, Decurion in Romula
item.description: Province Dacia Traiana Province Description Location Romula Romula (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Ael(ius) Iul(ius) Iulianus, Decurion in Romula Keywords tombs epitaphs Garden Description A slab unearthed near Resça (Romula), Romania, in 1954 records a verse epitaph set up by Valeria Gemellina for her husband Ael(ius) Iul(ius) Iulianus, a decurion of the colony of Romula, some time probably in the later second or third century. In it she describes in pastoral terms well suited to the hexameter the setting of the “eternal home” (i.

item.title: Rural Villa in Sudeley/Spoonley Wood
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Sudeley/Spoonley Wood (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Keywords axial plan terrace gardens villae rusticae Garden Description The main residence of this rural estate in Gloucestershire, excavated in 1882, is of the winged corridor type (Fig. 1). From the north and south corners of the house, walls ran in a westerly direction to enclose an open courtyard (G in Fig.

item.title: Rural Villa in Latimer
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Latimer Latimer (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Latimer Keywords fences (site elements) orchards villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations at this country house in Buckinghamshire have produced evidence for gardens adjacent to the main residence in its latest phase dating to the beginning of the 4th century (Fig. 1). The house at the west is of the winged corridor type, fronted by a large courtyard bisected by a paved central drive with a banked edge.

item.title: Rural Villa in Gorhambury
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gorhambury Gorhambury (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Gorhambury Keywords arbors axial plan loam villae rusticae Garden Description At this site in Hertfordshire near the town of Verulamium (St. Albans) excavations have revealed a multi-phased Roman farm, characterized in late Iron Age and Roman times by an outer courtyard with various service buildings and an inner courtyard in which the farm house stood (Fig.

item.title: Rural Estate in Gatcombe
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gatcombe Gatcombe (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Estate in Gatcombe Keywords barrier walls Garden Description This site of a large rural estate about 9 hectares in size in Somerset is enclosed within a massive wall (Fig.1). Although the site was not completely excavated, there is evidence to suggest that the main residence (A in Fig. 1) was located at the southern end of the complex, separated from various workshops and subsidiary buildings in the northern half by an area of cultivated soil.

item.title: Roman Palace in Fishbourne
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Fishbourne Fishbourne (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Roman Palace in Fishbourne Keywords colonnades palaces piscinae Garden Description Fishbourne Roman Palace was accidentally discovered during the digging of a water main trench in 1960. The discovery led to nine seasons of excavations (1961-69) that showed the site had developed from a military base at the time of the Roman invasion in AD 43 to a sumptuous palace by the end of the first century CE.

item.title: Atrium House
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Cologne Cologne (Pleiades) Location Description This large town on the west bank of the Rhine river was the civitas capital of the Ubii in the first half of the 1st century A.D. It was granted the status of colonia by Claudius in 50 and became the provincial capital in 85. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Atrium House (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium) Keywords urban villas villae urbanae atrium houses

item.title: House of Dionyius
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Cologne Cologne (Pleiades) Location Description This large town on the west bank of the Rhine river was the civitas capital of the Ubii in the first half of the 1st century A.D. It was granted the status of colonia by Claudius in 50 and became the provincial capital in 85. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden House of Dionysius (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium) Keywords urban villas villae urbanae

item.title: About
item.description: Gardens of the Roman Empire is a project created as part of the ISAW Library Summer Internship program. Editors June Dorsch Amartya Shri David Ratzan Christian Casey (Let’s put links in here to a list of edited articles or to an “about us” page.)

item.title: Rural Villa in Eccles
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Eccles Eccles (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Eccles Keywords piscinae villae rusticae water baths Garden Description This country estate in modern Kent possessed a large ornamental pool (P in Fig. 1) in the area in front of the main residence (A in Fig. 1) and to the east of the attached bath house (Fig. 1). The masonry pool measuring 25 x 3.

item.title: Rustic villa at Blankenheim-Hülchrath
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Blankenheim-Hülchrath Blankenheim-Hülchrath (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rustic villa at Blankenheim-Hülchrath Keywords rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description This villa rustica was built on a slope so that the residential building (A on Plan 1) overlooked the rest of the lower lying farmyard (Image 1). The entire complex covered an area 120 m. in width and 250 m. in length (3 hectares). The house was separated from a large open area behind and to the southwest of it by a wall.

item.title: Rural Villa in Darenth
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Darenth Darenth (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Darenth Keywords piscinae villae rusticae waterspouts Garden Description Excavations at this site of a Roman villa in Kent uncovered a large rectangular masonry pool in the courtyard, which was enclosed by buildings on the north, west, and east (Fig. 1). The villa buildings took up an area of 150 x 225 meters in total, including the courtyard with a width of 26.

item.title: Rural Villa in Chedworth
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Chedworth Chedworth (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Chedworth Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) mosaics (visual works) sherds villae rusticae Garden Description This Roman villa in Gloucestershire was partially excavated in the late 19th century, but only the built features and their mosaic floors appear to have been of interest to the Victorian diggers. Excavations in the courtyard conducted between 2000 and 2002 revealed that earlier excavators had not disturbed the courtyard.

item.title: Rural Villa in Bancroft
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Bancroft Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Bancroft Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) gazebos piscinae villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations between 1983 and 1986 at this site in Buckinghamshire revealed a Roman villa of the winged corridor type, which was built in the late 3rd century and rebuilt and enlarged in the mid-4th century (Fig.1). From the two projecting wings of the house at the northeast and southeast two walls ran eastward, forming an enclosed courtyard 35.

item.title: Suburban Gardens in Camulodunum
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Camulodunum Camulodunum (Pleiades) Location Description Camulodunum began as an Iron Age settlement defended by dykes, a combination of V-shaped ditch and rampart created by the upcast earth. It extended from the Roman river on the south to the Colne on the north, a distance of some four kilometers. Within this larger area, a legionary fort was built after the Claudian conquest of Britain in AD 43.
